**Elections to the United States Senate** will be held November 6, 2018, with
33 of the 100 seats in the [Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States
Senate") being contested in regular elections and two seats being contested in
special elections. The winners will serve six-year terms from January 3, 2019,
to January 3, 2025. Currently,
[Democrats](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\) "Democratic Party
\(United States\)") have 24 seats up for election, as well as the seats of two
independents who [caucus](/wiki/Caucus "Caucus") with them.
[Republicans](/wiki/Republican_Party_\(United_States\) "Republican Party
\(United States\)") have nine seats up for election. The seats up for regular
election in 2018 were last up for election in
[2012](/wiki/United_States_Senate_elections,_2012 "United States Senate
elections, 2012"); in addition, special elections will be scheduled if
vacancies occur, as has already happened in
[Minnesota](/wiki/United_States_Senate_special_election_in_Minnesota,_2018
"United States Senate special election in Minnesota, 2018") and
[Mississippi](/wiki/United_States_Senate_special_election_in_Mississippi,_2018
"United States Senate special election in Mississippi, 2018"). After the [2016
elections](/wiki/United_States_elections,_2016 "United States elections,
2016"), some state election officials are trying to upgrade voting systems in
time for this election.[3]

The [U.S. House of Representatives
elections](/wiki/United_States_House_of_Representatives_elections,_2018
"United States House of Representatives elections, 2018"), [39 gubernatorial
elections](/wiki/United_States_gubernatorial_elections,_2018 "United States
gubernatorial elections, 2018"), and many [other state and local
elections](/wiki/United_States_elections,_2018 "United States elections,
2018") will also be held on this date.

Republicans can only afford to lose one Senate seat and still have a working
majority with the Vice President breaking the tie in their favor. Four of the
Republican seats are open as a result of retirements in Tennessee, Utah,
Arizona, and Mississippi. Democrats are defending ten seats in states won by
[Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald Trump") in the [2016 presidential
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2016 "United States
presidential election, 2016"), while Republicans are only defending one seat
in a state won by [Hillary Clinton](/wiki/Hillary_Clinton "Hillary Clinton")
in 2016.

## Focus on competitive
races[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Senate_elections,_2018&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Focus on competitive races")]

Democrats are expected to target the Republican-held Senate seats in
[Arizona](/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Arizona,_2018 "United States
Senate election in Arizona, 2018") (open seat) and
[Nevada](/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Nevada,_2018 "United States
Senate election in Nevada, 2018").[4] Democrats could also target seats in
Texas,[5] Mississippi (At least one of the two seats) and Tennessee's open-
seat.[6] Republicans are expected to target Democratic-held seats in Indiana,
Missouri, Montana, North Dakota, and West Virginia, all of which voted for
[Mitt Romney](/wiki/Mitt_Romney "Mitt Romney") in the [2012 presidential
election](/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_2012 "United States
presidential election, 2012") and [Donald Trump](/wiki/Donald_Trump "Donald
Trump") in the 2016 presidential election,[7] as well as seats in Florida,
Ohio, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, and Michigan, all of which voted for Donald
Trump in the 2016 election.[8] Republicans could also target seats in
Minnesota (at least one of the two seats), Virginia, Maine, and New Jersey.[4]
Other races may also become competitive.

## Partisan
composition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Senate_elections,_2018&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Partisan composition")]

Among the 33 [Class 1](/wiki/Classes_of_United_States_Senators "Classes of
United States Senators") Senate seats up for regular election in 2018 are 23
currently held by Democrats, two by independents who [caucus with the Senate
Democrats](/wiki/Democratic_Caucus_of_the_United_States_Senate "Democratic
Caucus of the United States Senate"), and eight by Republicans. The Class 2
seats in Minnesota and Mississippi held by interim appointees are also up for
election.

## Most recent election

"Edit section: Most recent election predictions")]

Most election predictors use:

  * "_tossup_ ": no advantage
  * "_tilt_ " (used sometimes): advantage that is not quite as strong as "lean"
  * "_lean_ ": slight advantage
  * "_likely " or "favored_": significant, but surmountable, advantage
  * "_safe " or "solid_": near-certain chance of victory.

##
Arizona[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Senate_elections,_2018&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Arizona")]

Main article: [United States Senate election in Arizona,
2018](/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Arizona,_2018 "United States
Senate election in Arizona, 2018")

See also: [List of United States Senators from
Arizona](/wiki/List_of_United_States_Senators_from_Arizona "List of United
States Senators from Arizona")

One-term Republican [Jeff Flake](/wiki/Jeff_Flake "Jeff Flake") was elected
with 49% of the vote in 2012. He will be 55 years old in 2018. He has declared
he will retire at the end of his term.[109]

In 2016, Republican [John McCain](/wiki/John_McCain "John McCain") was [re-
elected to a sixth term](/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Arizona,_2016
"United States Senate election in Arizona, 2016") in the Senate. However,
Senator McCain has been diagnosed with an aggressive brain tumor.[110] If
Senator McCain's seat becomes vacant, Arizona law[111] requires that the
vacancy be filled at the next general election. If this were to occur in 2018,
then both Senate seats in Arizona would be up for election simultaneously.

U.S. Representative [Martha McSally](/wiki/Martha_McSally "Martha
McSally"),[27] former state senator [Kelli Ward](/wiki/Kelli_Ward "Kelli
Ward"),[27] owner, co-founder of [IsAnybodyDown?](/wiki/IsAnybodyDown%3F
"IsAnybodyDown?") Craig Brittain,[29] Christian "C.J." Diegel,[30] pharmacist
Nicolas Tutora,[38] former Maricopa County Sheriff [Joe
Arpaio](/wiki/Joe_Arpaio "Joe Arpaio"),[27] and Michelle Griffin[31] will
contest the Republican primary.

U.S. Rep. [Kyrsten Sinema](/wiki/Kyrsten_Sinema "Kyrsten Sinema"),[27] Deedra
Abboud,[27] airshow pilot Bob Bishop,[28] Chris Russell,[36] and former Member
of the Iowa House of Representatives [Richard Sherzan](/wiki/Richard_Sherzan
"Richard Sherzan")[37] are running for the Democratic nomination.

Eve Reyes Aguirre is running as a Green Party Candidate.[27]

California[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Senate_elections,_2018&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: California")]

Four-term Democrat [Dianne Feinstein](/wiki/Dianne_Feinstein "Dianne
Feinstein") won a special election in 1992 and was elected to full terms in
1994, 2000, 2006, and 2012. She will be 85 years old in 2018. She is running
for re-election.[39]

Democratic candidates aside from Feinstein include [President pro tempore of
the California State
Senate](/wiki/President_pro_tempore_of_the_California_State_Senate "President
pro tempore of the California State Senate") [Kevin de
León](/wiki/Kevin_de_Le%C3%B3n "Kevin de León"),[39] community advocate
Adrienne Nicole Edwards,[39] [Eugene Patterson
Harris](/wiki/Eugene_Patterson_Harris "Eugene Patterson Harris"),[39] David
Hildebrand, Douglas Howard Pierce,[39] and Alison Hartson.[39]

Republican candidates include Paul Allen Taylor.[39]

Derrick Michael Reid is running with the Libertarian Party.[39]

Independent candidates include biologist Tim Gildersleeve,[39] Lee W.
Olson,[39] and evangelist Ling Ling Shi.[39]

One-term Democrat [Chris Murphy](/wiki/Chris_Murphy "Chris Murphy") was
elected with 55% of the vote in 2012. He will be 45 years old in 2018. He is
running for re-election.[43] He is being challenged for the Democratic
nomination by [Ann-Marie Adams](/wiki/Ann-Marie_Adams "Ann-Marie Adams").[44]

Businessmen Matthew Corey[45] and Dominic Rapini[46] are seeking the
Republican nomination.

States Senators from Delaware")

Three-term Democrat [Tom Carper](/wiki/Tom_Carper "Tom Carper") won re-
election with 66% of the vote in 2012. He will be 71 years old in 2018. He
announced he was running for re-election during an interview on
[MSNBC](/wiki/MSNBC "MSNBC") on July 24, 2017.[47] He will be challenged by
Kerri Evelyn Harris for the Democratic nomination.

Sussex County Councilman Robert Arlett and Businessman Gene Truono are running
for the Republican nomination.

Florida[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Senate_elections,_2018&action=edit&section=15

States Senators from Florida")

Three-term Democrat [Bill Nelson](/wiki/Bill_Nelson_\(politician\) "Bill
Nelson \(politician\)") was re-elected with 55% of the vote in 2012. Nelson
will be 76 years old in 2018. He will seek re-election to a fourth term in
office.[50] He is being challenged for the Democratic nomination by Tamika
Lyles.[50]

Florida Governor [Rick Scott](/wiki/Rick_Scott "Rick Scott") has announced his
candidacy for the Republican nomination. Scott will be 65 years old in 2018.
First elected in [2010](/wiki/Florida_gubernatorial_election,_2010 "Florida
gubernatorial election, 2010") and re-elected in
[2014](/wiki/Florida_gubernatorial_election,_2014 "Florida gubernatorial
election, 2014"), Scott's term as [Governor of
Florida](/wiki/Governor_of_Florida "Governor of Florida") is set to end by
January 2019, due to [term limits](/wiki/Term_limits "Term limits").[50]
Lateresa Ann Jones,[50] Howard Knepper,[50] and Joe Smith,[50] are also
running for the Republican nomination.

Edward Janowski is running as independents.[50]

One-term Independent Senator [Angus King](/wiki/Angus_King "Angus King") was
elected in a three-way race with 53% of the vote in 2012. King has caucused
with the [Democratic Party](/wiki/Democratic_Party_\(United_States\)
"Democratic Party \(United States\)") since taking office in 2013, but he has
left open the possibility of caucusing with the Republican Party in the
future.[113]

King has indicated he will seek re-election.[114] [54] He will be 74 years old
in 2018.

State Senator [Eric Brakey](/wiki/Eric_Brakey "Eric Brakey") is running for
the Republican nomination.[115]

Public school teacher and founder of UClass Zak Ringelstein is seeking the
Democratic nomination.[116]

Shlikas[58] are running.

Television producer Bruce Jacobson,[125] Houston energy attorney Stefano de
Stefano,[126] former mayor of [La Marque](/wiki/La_Marque,_TX "La Marque, TX")
Geraldine Sam,[127] Mary Miller,[128] and Thomas Dillingham[129] were Cruz's
opponents.

the Democratic nomination on March 6, 2018.[130] Other Democrats who ran

Nurse Carl Bible ran as an independent.[93]

##
Utah[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Senate_elections,_2018&action=edit&section=39
"Edit section: Utah")]

Main article: [United States Senate election in Utah,
2018](/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Utah,_2018 "United States Senate
election in Utah, 2018")

See also: [List of United States Senators from
Utah](/wiki/List_of_United_States_Senators_from_Utah "List of United States
Senators from Utah")

Seven-term Republican [Orrin Hatch](/wiki/Orrin_Hatch "Orrin Hatch") was re-
elected with 65% of the vote in 2012. Hatch is the [President pro tempore of
the United States
Senate](/wiki/President_pro_tempore_of_the_United_States_Senate "President pro
tempore of the United States Senate"), as well as the [second most-senior
Senator](/wiki/Seniority_in_the_United_States_Senate "Seniority in the United
States Senate"). He will be 84 years old in 2018. Before the 2012 election,
Hatch said that he would retire at the end of his seventh term if he was re-
elected.[133] Hatch initially announced his re-election campaign on March 9,
2017,[134][135] but later announced his plans to retire on January 2, 2018.
2012 Republican presidential candidate [Mitt Romney](/wiki/Mitt_Romney "Mitt
Romney") is running for the seat. Attorney Larry Meyers is also running for
the Republican nomination.[100]

Professor James Singer was running for the Democratic nomination, but he
dropped out and endorsed Salt Lake County Councilwoman [Jenny
Wilson](/wiki/Jenny_Wilson_\(politician\) "Jenny Wilson \(politician\)"), who
made her Senate bid official on July 17, 2017.[136][137] Danny Drew[138][139]
also was running but dropped out and endorsed [Jenny
Wilson](/wiki/Jenny_Wilson_\(politician\) "Jenny Wilson \(politician\)").
Mitchell Kent Vice is also running for the Democratic nomination.

##
Vermont[[edit](/w/index.php?title=United_States_Senate_elections,_2018&action=edit&section=40
"Edit section: Vermont")]

Main article: [United States Senate election in Vermont,
2018](/wiki/United_States_Senate_election_in_Vermont,_2018 "United States
Senate election in Vermont, 2018")

See also: [List of United States Senators from
Vermont](/wiki/List_of_United_States_Senators_from_Vermont "List of United
States Senators from Vermont")

Two-term Independent Senator [Bernie Sanders](/wiki/Bernie_Sanders "Bernie
Sanders") was re-elected with 71% of the vote in 2012. Sanders, one of two
independent members of Congress, has caucused with the Democratic Party since
taking office in 2007. In November 2015, Sanders announced his plans to run as
a Democrat, rather than an Independent, in all future elections. He will be 77
years old in 2018.[140] On July 28, 2016, Sanders announced he would return to
the Senate as an Independent, and two days later, in an interview on _[Real
Time with Bill Maher](/wiki/Real_Time_with_Bill_Maher "Real Time with Bill
Maher")_ , he said that he would run for re-election.[141]

In 2016, activist and journalist [Al Giordano](/wiki/Al_Giordano "Al
Giordano") stated his intention to challenge Sanders for the Democratic
nomination to protest [Sanders's 2016 presidential
campaign](/wiki/Bernie_Sanders_presidential_campaign,_2016 "Bernie Sanders
presidential campaign, 2016"), which Giordano claims has divided the
Democratic Party.[142][143][144] In 2017, however, Giordano announced he would
not run for the seat.[145] Folasade Adeluola are running for the Democratic
nomination.[101]

elected with 76% of the vote in 2012. Barrasso was appointed to the seat in
2007, and won a special election in 2008. He will be 66 years old in 2018. He
is running.[107]

58 year old [Gary Trauner](/wiki/Gary_Trauner "Gary Trauner")[107], a Jackson
Hole businessman and US House candidate in 2006 and 2008, is running for the
Democratic nomination.

Businessman Dave Dodson is running as an independent.[108]
